purpose: Renders an interactive multi-series timeline chart of simulation events (pressure updates, template applications, system actions) with tick-level selection, locking, and event highlighting
Displays a positioned tooltip overlay with tick-specific pressure values or event details when the user hovers over the simulation trace chart
Transforms a verb or noun into its agentive form (one who does X) by applying English morphological rules and irregular forms
Transforms a word into its superlative form (most X, e.g. deep -> deepest) by applying English morphological rules and irregular forms
Transforms a word into its comparative form (more X, e.g. dark -> darker) by applying English morphological rules and irregular forms
Transforms a verb into its gerund or present-participle form (X-ing) by applying English morphological rules
Transforms a verb into its past or passive participle form (X-ed) by applying English morphological rules and irregular forms
Transforms a noun into its English possessive form by appending an apostrophe or apostrophe-s based on the word's ending
Dispatches a word to the appropriate morphological transformation function based on a derivation type code (er, est, ing, ed, poss, comp)
Type-guards a string to confirm it is a valid DerivationType code from the known set
Generates a batch of culturally-appropriate names by selecting grammar strategies, preloading Markov models, and running the phonotactic or grammar pipeline according to a culture's configuration
Generates a single name for a specific entity kind using a culture's configuration, as a convenience wrapper over the multi-name generate function
Generates a list of names directly from a naming domain's phonology configuration without requiring a full culture or grammar profile
Generates sample names from a domain and computes uniqueness and length statistics to support validation metrics
Generates a small set of sample names from a grammar definition to provide live UI previews of grammar output

Evaluates whether names generated by a domain are sufficiently distinct from one another by measuring nearest-neighbor distance distributions
